instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no  <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G_PH2</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no  <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G_PH2</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no  <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G_PH2</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I bet missing <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0G_PH1</SIGNAL>/3 too.
You must fix on common output point, after the coils.
But that voltage will only upper under high graphics load, like playing YouTube.
The problem there is you don't get <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G</SIGNAL>.
Even <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0G</SIGNAL> (L7370) doesn't look good; as <SIGNAL>PP1V_OPC_S0</SIGNAL> (L7730) too.

"L7900 .1025 v
L8060 .1000 v"
Start there, S5 voltages should appear before all others above mentioned.
